en.value: I've just started a new job!
Talking about different departments, learning useful office vocabulary.
At work

In this unit we are going to look at some useful vocabulary to talk about the workplace. A company usually has different departments. They are responsible for different areas of work. You can see some examples of different departments below.
Finance
IT (Information Technology)
Marketing
Customer Service
HR (Human Resources)
Here's a tip!
The finance department is responsible for the company's bank account.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
I work in the finance [k]department[/k].
depart
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
The [k]f[/k][k]i[/k][k]n[/k][k]a[/k][k]n[/k][k]c[/k]e department is responsible for the company's bank account.
The [k]finance[/k] department is responsible for the company's bank account.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
The IT department is on the third floor.
What does IT stand for?
Information Technology
Intelligent Technology
Inter Technology
The marketing department is the biggest team in the company.
A company can have many different departments.
True or false?
The [k]marketing[/k] department is the biggest team in the [k]company[/k].
markets
department
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
A department can consist of different teams. A team is a group of people working on specific projects. In smaller organisations, department and team can be used as synonyms.
Their customer service team receives a lot of complaints.
Customer service...
helps customers with problems and requests.
is responsible for the company's bank account.
is the same as the IT department.
The management team had a meeting last week.
The management [k]team[/k] had a meeting last week.
company
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
team
Finance
Customer Service
a group of people who work on a specific project
a department that is responsible for the company's money
a department that is responsible for solving customer problems
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
The HR department is in charge of recruitment.
"To be in charge of something" means the same as "to be responsible for something". The verb "to lead" also has a similar meaning. Have a look at the examples below.
Ross and I are in charge of this project.
Ross and I are responsible for this project.
Ross and I are leading this project.
HR stands for...
Human Resources
High Resources
Home Resources
Click on the names of different departments.
[h]IT[/h] team [h]Finance[/h] [h]HR[/h] customer

The HR department...
The Marketing department...
The IT department...
is in charge of the recruitment process.
promotes the business and sales.
is responsible for information technology systems.
The [k]management[/k] [k]team[/k] had a meeting last week.
manage
service
What department is in charge of the organisation's money?
Finance
IT
Customer Service
I am applying for a job in the [k]IT[/k] department.
ET
Their [k]customer[/k] service team receives a lot of complaints.
costumers
The HR department is [k]in[/k] [k]charge[/k] of recruitment.
on
responsible
What department is responsible for promotion and sales?
Marketing
IT
Customer Service

responsible [h]team[/h] service company [h]department[/h]
The [k]IT[/k] department is on the third floor.
stands for Information Technology
Fill in the gap using the hint.
The [k]finance department[/k] is responsible for the company's bank account.
Type what you hear.
The [k]management[/k] team had a meeting last week.
Ross and I are [k]leading[/k] this project.
charging
Their customer service [k]team|department[/k] receives a lot of complaints.

Thomas is the [k]marketing[/k] manager.
Complete the sentence by writing in the box.
The [k]Human Resources[/k] department is in charge of recruitment.
the full version of HR
Office Talk
In this lesson we'll learn some everyday language which you'll hear in the workplace.
John has a full schedule this week, he will not be able to see you.

The word "schedule" can be used as both a noun and a verb. As a noun "schedule" means the same as diary, while as a verb it means "to organise, to set a time" to do something. You will also hear it pronounced in different ways. In British English it is pronounced with a "sh" sound (like "shed-ule"). In American English it is pronounced with a "sk" sound (like "sked-ule").
Can we schedule a meeting? (verb)
Let me check my schedule. (noun)
I am too busy today. Can we reschedule the meeting?
In this sentence "schedule" is used as a verb.
In this sentence "schedule" is used as a noun.
Can we [k]r[/k][k]e[/k][k]s[/k][k]c[/k][k]h[/k][k]e[/k][k]d[/k][k]u[/k]le the meeting?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
The word "meeting" comes from the verb "to meet". An important room in most workplaces is the "meeting room", where groups of people can sit and have private conversations.
Your desk is right next to the meeting room.
Have you booked the [k]meeting[/k] [k]room[/k]?
meet
to
I have a catch-up with Christiane at 2pm.
Do we have a catch-up today? (noun)
I need to catch up with the marketing team. (verb)
Sarah is working this weekend because she needs to catch up on the project. (verb)

A catch-up is usually a quick meeting to discuss the latest news or progress on a project. "Catch up" can also be used as a verb with the same meaning. The verb can also mean "to do something you did not have time to do earlier". After the verb "to catch up" we use the prepositions "on" or "with". Note that we write the noun with a hyphen (-) and the verb as two separate words!
Shall we grab a coffee and catch up this afternoon?
I have a [k]catch-up[/k] with Christiane at 2pm.
meeting
catch-up
meeting room
schedule
a short meeting to discuss the latest news
a space where people meet to talk in private
a plan of your time

A lot of everyday language in the workplace is connected to time: everything needs to happen quickly and efficiently so that time isn't wasted. That's why in English we "grab a coffee" instead of "have a coffee", we ask our colleagues if they "have a minute" instead of "some time" and we ask a "quick" question.
Do you have a minute?
Can I ask a quick question?
Do you have a [k]minute[/k]?
moment
This means the same as "have a coffee", but it implies it will be quicker.
Shall we grab a coffee?
Can I ask a [k]quick[/k] [k]question[/k]?
questions
minute
I get on well with my team. They are all very friendly!
If you "get on" with someone it means that you have a good relationship with them. The verb "to get along" with someone has the same meaning.
Do you get [k]along[/k] with James?
long
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Hi Alexander, did you remember we have a [k]meeting[/k] later?
Oh no! I am so busy today, can we [k]reschedule[/k] it for tomorrow?
Of course, don't worry. I have a [k]catch-up[/k] with Sophie in the morning, but I'm free in the afternoon. Shall we say 2 p.m.?
Yes, that would be great! Thank you!
No worries, I'll try to book the [k]meeting room[/k] on the second floor for 2 o'clock then.
Amazing.
By the way, how are you [k]getting on[/k] with the new intern in your team?
Oh, he's great, we get along really well... Actually, I wanted to ask you a [k]quick question[/k] about his contract, do you have a minute?
Sure, I was just going to [k]grab[/k] a coffee, do you want to join me?
Martha
Alexander
Martha and Alexander are colleagues.

has a full schedule today.
will go to the meeting with Martha today.
is not very busy today.
Martha is only free in the morning.
Martha is busy in the morning, she's free in the afternoon.
has a new intern in his team.
is an intern in Martha's team.
wants to talk about Martha's contract.
Have you booked the [k]meeting room[/k]?

he will not be able to see you.
and catch up this afternoon?
quick question?

grabs

I [k]get on|get along[/k] well with my team. They are all very friendly!
To "reschedule a meeting" means...
to find another time for a meeting.
to attend a meeting.
to forget about a meeting.
[k]Do you have a minute?[/k]
Do we have a [k]catch[/k]-[k]up[/k] this afternoon?

on

Sarah needs to catch up [k]on|with[/k] the project.
Can I ask a [k]quick question[/k]?
to get on well
to schedule
to have a good relationship
to decide on a time for something
